title: Home are the handball heroes as victorious World Championship stars return to Shannon laden with medalsTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Home are the handball heroes as victorious World Championship stars return to Shannon laden with medals
Home are the handball heroes as victorious World Championship stars return to Shannon laden with medals It was another glorious sporting homecoming at Shannon Airport this week as handballers returned laden with medals – 18 in all – from the world handball championships in Calgary, Canada.
In all, some 14 Clare handballers claimed medals from the championships, which were held from August 11th to 21st. The medal haul included triple gold for one of the country’s leading young handballers, Tiarnan Agnew. Competing in the U-15 grade and wearing the Team Ireland jersey, the Kilkishen Handball Club star took top honours in the 40×20 singles.
Agnew followed this up with another gold, in the 40×20 doubles, as well as gold in the One-Wall doubles in which he was partnered by Cormac Munroe from Tyrone.
It was a championships to remember for the Kilkishen club, with Chloe Philpott winning gold in the 40×20 singles, gold in One-Wall Doubles and silver in 40×20 doubles. Also representing Kilkishen, Colin Crehan took silver in the 40×20 U-23 singles; Ella Donnellan won silver in the 40×20 U-17 doubles, while Pat Donnellan won gold in the Veteran Gold Masters B (55+) 40×20 singles.
The flag of Tuamgraney, another of Clare’s handball strongholds, was also flown proudly on the world stage at the championships as two members of the club emerged with medals, Nash sibblings Diarmuid and Clodagh. Diarmuid, with Robbie McCarthy of Westmeath as his partner, took gold in the prestigious Men’s Open 40×20, while Clodagh teamed up with Tipperary’s Sinead Maher to claim top honours in the U-17 40×20 doubles.
Tulla’s Colin Corbett, also representing Team Ireland, added to his growing reputation with silver in the U-19 40×20 doubles with Tipperary’s Daniel Hayes. The Tulla club also claimed medals through Brídín Dinan, who took gold in the 40×20 doubles in an all-Clare partnership with Broadford’s Caitriona Millane. Another Tulla star, Aoife Floyd, partnered with Kildare’s Leah Doyle and went all the way to the final before taking silver in the U-15 One-Wall doubles The Clooney Quinn club also had a memorable championship with Fergal Couglan taking a silver home from the U-17 40×20 singles and his sister Natasha Coughlan doing likewise in both the 40×20 singles and One-Wall. Clarecastle’s Doireann Murphy took silver in the 40×20 U-17 doubles with partner Ella Donnellan.
Clarecastle’s Doireann Murphy was another Clare winner, taking silver in the 40×20 U-17 doubles with partner Ella Donnellan.
Speaking on arrival back in Shannon on Monday, Bernie Agnew, mother of triple gold medal winner Tiarnan, said that Clare’s handball success on the world stage very much reflects it is in good health at the moment.
“It’s great to be coming back into Shannon Airport and Clare with all these medals. There’s a fantastic tradition of handball in Clare and it is undergoing a real revival over recent years. There’s huge effort being put in by players and coaches and the fantastic return from Calgary reflects that.
“For Clare to take 18 medals home from the world championships is a huge performance and with so many of them also coming from the younger age groupings, it suggests that we are well set up for the future.”
Welcoming the handball heroes back to Shannon, Head of Marketing at Shannon Group Marie Slattery said, “This is a great achievement for Clare and there were other counties in our region who also did very well from the championships, including Limerick and Tipperary, so handball is very much alive and well in this part of the country. We have had the privilege of welcoming home many Irish sport stars following international successes over the years and our handballers definitely deserve their moment in the sun.”
Source:- Shannon Airport
